findings.title: US - Untrusted Source
findings.description: The contract uses an external contract to determine the transaction's flow, but the external contract is untrusted, which may produce security issues and harm transactions.

findings.title: PTRP - Potential Transfer Revert Propagation
findings.description: The contract sends funds to a `marketingWallet` , `developmentWallet` as part of the transfer flow. This address can either be a wallet address or a contract. If the address belongs to a contract then it may revert from incoming payment. As a result, the error will propagate to the token’s contract and revert the transfer.

findings.title: PVC - Price Volatility Concern
findings.description: The contract accumulates tokens from taxes to swap them for ETH, but the variable `swapTokensAtAmount` can be set to a big number, leading to significant price volatility for the parties involved.

findings.title: RSML - Redundant SafeMath Library
findings.description: The usage of the SafeMath library adds complexity, overhead and increases the gas consumption unnecessarily since Solidity versions 0.8.0 and above have native functionality that reverts on underflow and overflow.

findings.title: RSK - Redundant Storage Keyword
findings.description: The contract uses the `storage` keyword in a view function. The `storage` keyword is used to persist data on the contract's storage. View functions are functions that do not modify the state of the contract and do not perform any actions that cost gas (such as sending a transaction). As a result, the use of the `storage` keyword in view functions is redundant.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure they cannot be changed after being set and decrease gas consumption.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity naming conventions, which can affect readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L05 - Unused State Variable
findings.description: An unused state variable is a state variable that is declared in the contract, but is never used in any of the contract's functions.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract. They are often used to notify external parties or clients about events that have occurred within the contract, such as the transfer of tokens or the completion of a task.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.

findings.title: L11 - Unnecessary Boolean equality
findings.description: Boolean equality is unnecessary when comparing two boolean values.

findings.title: L12 - Using Variables before Declaration
findings.description: The contract is using a variable before the declaration. This is usually happening either if it has not been declared yet or if the variable has been declared in a different scope.

findings.title: L13 - Divide before Multiply Operation
findings.description: Performing divisions before multiplications may cause loss of precision.

findings.title: L14 - Uninitialized Variables in Local Scope
findings.description: Using an uninitialized local variable can lead to unpredictable behavior and potentially cause errors in the contract.

findings.title: L15 - Local Scope Variable Shadowing
findings.description: Local scope variable shadowing occurs when a local variable with the same name as a variable in an outer scope is declared within a function or code block.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables that have been configured on user-supplied input without proper check for the case where a value is zero, leading to problems when the contract is executed.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.

findings.title: L20 - Succeeded Transfer Check
findings.description: According to the ERC20 specification, the transfer methods should be checked if the result is successful. Otherwise, the contract may wrongly assume that the transfer has been established.
